qas.question: What term described the method used to regulate common practice and or order?
Which document is an important confessional document second only to the Bible?
What other name is used when referring to the origins of the Presbyterian Church?
What is another term for institutional doctrine?
Which book to Muslims use to regulate common practice and order?
Where are the origins of Faith in?
Which document is even more important than the Bible, serving as an important confessional document?
Some combinations have been due to what type of controversy?

context: Presbyterians distinguish themselves from other denominations by doctrine, institutional organization (or "<b3_0>church order<b3_0/>") and worship; often using a "<a0_0><b4_0>Book of Order<b4_0/><a0_0/>" to regulate common practice and order. The origins of the Presbyterian churches are in <a2_0><b5_0>Calvinism<b5_0/><a2_0/>. Many branches of Presbyterianism are remnants of previous splits from larger groups. Some of the splits have been due to <b7_0>doctrinal controversy<b7_0/>, while some have been caused by disagreement concerning the degree to which those ordained to church office should be required to agree with the <a1_0><b6_0>Westminster Confession of Faith<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which historically serves as an important confessional document – second only to the Bible, yet directing particularities in the standardization and translation of the Bible – in Presbyterian churches.
